message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A 2-cm intrasellar mass and positive hormone assay suggest prolactinoma, which is treated with dopamine agonists like Cabergoline. Observation is not appropriate given the size of the tumor, and biopsy is not usually necessary to diagnose prolactinomas. Temozolomide is not used in the treatment of prolactinomas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the MRI findings suggest a prolactinoma. Cabergoline therapy is the first-line treatment for prolactinomas. Observation and outpatient follow-up is not appropriate as the patient has hormonal imbalances and a mass in her brain. Biopsy of intrasellar mass or temozolomide therapy are not indicated as the patient has a high likelihood of a prolactinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a pituitary adenoma, which is confirmed by the cranial MRI and hormone assay. Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that is commonly used to treat prolactin-secreting pituitary adenomas. Observation is not appropriate as the adenoma may continue to grow and cause further complications. Biopsy is not necessary as the diagnosis is already confirmed by the MRI and hormone assay. Temozolomide is used for treating malignant brain tumors and is not appropriate for a pituitary adenoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and MRI findings suggest a pituitary adenoma, which can cause hormonal imbalances. Cabergoline therapy is appropriate for treating dopamine-secreting adenomas, which are the most common type of hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas. Observation and outpatient follow-up would not address the hormonal imbalances. Biopsy of the intrasellar mass would be invasive and unnecessary for diagnosing a pituitary adenoma. Temozolomide therapy is used for treating malignant brain tumors, which is not the diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the positive hormone assay suggest a pituitary adenoma. Cabergoline therapy, a dopamine agonist, can help suppress prolactin secretion and reduce tumor size. Observation and outpatient follow-up would not address the underlying issue. Biopsy may be appropriate in some cases but is not the first step in management. Temozolomide therapy is used for malignant brain tumors and would not be appropriate in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the presence of an intrasellar mass suggest a prolactinoma. Cabergoline therapy is the first-line treatment for prolactinoma. Observation and outpatient follow-up would not address the underlying issue. Biopsy may not be necessary since the hormone assay is positive for prolactinoma. Temozolomide therapy is not indicated for prolactinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The 2-cm intrasellar mass with positive hormone assay suggests a prolactinoma, which can cause headaches and menstrual disturbances. Cabergoline therapy is the initial treatment for prolactinoma. Observation and outpatient follow-up is not appropriate for a confirmed diagnosis of prolactinoma. Biopsy is not necessary for a prolactinoma diagnosis. Temozolomide therapy is used for malignant brain tumors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intrasellar mass and the hormone assay suggest a prolactinoma. Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that is effective in reducing prolactin levels and shrinking prolactinomas. Observation and outpatient follow-up would not be appropriate given the presence of a hormone-secreting tumor. Biopsy of the intrasellar mass may not be necessary given the strong clinical suspicion for a prolactinoma, and temozolomide therapy is not indicated for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging suggest a pituitary adenoma, and the positive hormone assay further confirms it. Cabergoline therapy, a medication that reduces the secretion of prolactin, is the most appropriate next step in the management. Observation and outpatient follow-up is not recommended as the mass requires treatment. Biopsy of the mass may further damage the pituitary gland, which should be avoided. Temozolomide therapy is used for the treatment of brain tumors, but not for pituitary adenomas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the MRI suggest a pituitary adenoma. The positive hormone assay indicates hyperprolactinemia, which can cause the patient’s menstrual changes and decreased sexual interest. Cabergoline therapy is the treatment of choice for prolactinomas. Observation and outpatient follow-up may be an option for small non-functioning adenomas, but not for symptomatic functioning adenomas. Biopsy is not the first-line management for pituitary adenomas. Temozolomide therapy is used for malignant pituitary tumors and is not appropriate for a prolactinoma.
